statements.text: Heracles, son of Zeus and the mortal Alcmene, is praised in Greek song for his prodigious strength and stormy life.
Hera resents Heracles as the living proof of Zeus’s unfaithfulness and becomes his enemy from the day he is born.
Alcmene endures the wrath of Hera as she raises Heracles, knowing that the queen of the gods lashes out against the boy and his mother alike.
In adulthood, a madness sent by Hera seizes Heracles so that he kills his wife Megara and their children, and blood-guilt hangs over him like a shadow.
To purify this crime, an oracle decrees that Heracles must obey King Eurystheus and undertake a series of great labors.
Eurystheus is a timid ruler who fears the very strength he commands and hides himself away whenever rumors of the hero’s return reach his ears.
The Nemean Lion is said to have a hide no spear or arrow can pierce, and its lair becomes a byword among Greeks for an almost invincible foe.
Heracles strangles the Nemean Lion with his bare hands and later wears its skin and gaping jaws as a cloak and helmet.
In the struggle with the Lernaean Hydra, Heracles hacks at the snapping heads while his kinsman Iolaus burns the necks to keep them from multiplying.
Stories of the Lernaean Hydra spread the saying that some troubles, like the monster’s heads, seem to grow back stronger whenever they are cut down.
Eurystheus orders that the Augean Stables, choked with filth from countless cattle, be cleansed in a single day as one of the appointed labors.
King Augeas promises a rich reward to the one who can cleanse the Augean Stables, but he later tries to deny the bargain when he sees how quickly the task is done.
In the task of driving off the Stymphalian Birds, Athena gives Heracles a brazen rattle whose harsh clamor startles the flock into flight.
Heracles masters the Cretan Bull and brings the snorting beast to Eurystheus, who is said to cower at the sight of his captive prize.
In another far-roaming labor, Heracles seizes the cattle of the giant Geryon and drives them back across strange lands as a living sign of his endurance.
Some poets tell how the golden apples of a distant garden, guarded by divine powers, are taken at last and counted among the greatest of Heracles’s labors.
For his descent to the Underworld, Heracles wrestles Cerberus, the three-headed hound, and bears it upward without using blade or arrow.
In Greek imagination, the Underworld is a shadowy realm where Cerberus keeps watch at the gates and souls drift far from the sunlight of the living.
Later in his wandering life, Heracles wins Deianira as his wife after contending with other suitors for her hand.
The centaur Nessus, struck down by Deianira’s husband for assaulting her, leaves behind a deceptive token that will one day bring ruin to the hero.
Trusting Nessus’s words, Deianira later sends her husband a garment steeped in the centaur’s blood, believing it will preserve his love.
When the poisoned garment is put on, Deianira realizes too late that Nessus’s promise was a trap, for the cloth clings to the wearer’s skin and burns with unending pain.
On Mount Oeta, the suffering hero has a great pyre built and lies upon it so that mortal weakness may be burned away.
Zeus is moved by the hero’s torment on Mount Oeta and sends a thunderbolt that consumes the pyre, signaling that his son will not remain among mortals.
After this transformation, the hero is said to dwell on Mount Olympus among the gods, freed at last from the service of Eurystheus.
On Mount Olympus, Heracles is joined in marriage to Hebe, and the once-tormented hero is honored at the feasts of the gods.
